rename.from: False-positive errors when using `type[T]` (or Type[T]`) in a PEP 604 type alias
rename.to: False-positive errors when using `type[T]` (or `Type[T]`) in a PEP 604 type alias

issue.title: False-positive error when using `Callable` in a PEP 604 type alias

labels.name: false-positive
labels.description: mypy gave an error on correct code

labels.name: topic-type-alias
labels.description: TypeAlias and other type alias issues

labels.name: affects-typeshed
labels.description: Anything that blocks a typeshed change

issue.body:
**Bug Report**

The following snippet works fine at runtime on 3.10+. It should be accepted as a valid type alias definition on Python 3.10+ (and should be accepted in stub files regardless of Python version). However, mypy raises a false-positive error. The error does not go away if you use `typing.TypeAlias`:

```python
from typing import Callable, TypeAlias

A = Callable[[], str] | int  # error: Unsupported left operand type for | ("object")
B: TypeAlias = Callable[[], str] | int  # error: Unsupported left operand type for | ("object")
```

Mypy _does_ accept the following (with the order of types reversed) as a valid type alias on Python 3.10+ and in stub files:

```python
C = int | Callable[[], str]  # No error using Python 3.10 (in a `.py file), or in a stub file on any Python version.
```

Much like with #12392, this error is only reproduceable if `Callable` is the outermost type. The following produces no errors:

```python
D = list[Callable[[], str] | int]
```

There is also an additional bug that only exists for stub files running with `--python-version` set to 3.9 or lower, when using a `Callable` that has a PEP 604 union as its return type or a PEP 604 union in its parameter specification, and when the `Callable` is itself in a PEP 604 union:

```python
X = int | Callable[[], str | bool]  # error: Unsupported left operand type for | ("Type[str]")
Y = int | Callable[[str | bool], str]  # error: Unsupported left operand type for | ("Type[str]")
```

**To Reproduce**

- Mypy playground link [here](https://mypy-play.net/?mypy=latest&python=3.10&gist=18c29b7bef9d61e8a29af292863d1072) for the errors which affect stubs and `.py` files.
- For the stub-specific errors, paste the code samples into a `.pyi` file, then run mypy on the file with `--python-version=3.9`.

**Expected Behavior**

No errors should be reported.

Cc. @JelleZijlstra

issue.title: PEP 604: Remove some more uses of Union/Optional

repository.name: typeshed
repository.description: Collection of library stubs for Python, with static types

issue.body:
Mypy seems fine with these. Aliases that use type[] or variadic tuple[]
still break mypy.

issue.title: PEP 604 (Unions with pipe character) tracker

labels.name: project: feature tracker
labels.description: Tracks whether a typing feature can be used in typeshed stubs

repository.name: typeshed
repository.description: Collection of library stubs for Python, with static types

issue.body:
This issue is supposed to track when we can start to use the pipe character as union ([PEP 604](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0604/)) in typeshed. Support is needed in released versions of:

* [x] mypy (python/mypy#9610), mostly works, except (full list of related issues [here](https://github.com/python/mypy/labels/topic-pep-604)):
    * [x] Type aliases (python/mypy#10901)
    * [x] https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/12392
    * [x] https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/12393
    * [x] https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/11098
    * [x] https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/14158
* [x] pytype (google/pytype#924)
* [x] pyright (microsoft/pyright#659)
* [x] pyre
* [x] PyCharm ([PY-44974](https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/PY-44974))

body:
I have encountered the following
```
import typing as tp
from collections.abc import Coroutine

T = tp.TypeVar('T')

F: tp.TypeAlias = tp.Callable[[], T] | tp.Callable[[], Coroutine[None, None, T]]  # Unsupported left operand type for | ("object")
G: tp.TypeAlias = tp.Callable[[], T | Coroutine[None, None, T]]  # ok
```
It looks like the same issue?
@wrobell, I have another issue open for PEP-604 false-positives with respect to `Callable`: #12393. But I agree that these problems are linked.

issue.title: Release 0.950 planning

labels.name: meta
labels.description: Issues tracking a broad area of work

issue.body:
I'm planning to make a 0.950 release by Apr 22 (tentative timeline).

Please post here any issues you'd like to see fixed in the release, or PRs you'd like to have merged.  I've already cut the release branch, but we can still cherry-pick low-risk features and bug fixes until Apr 18. After Apr 18 only critical bug fixes and documentation updates should be cherry-picked.

issue.title: Fix exception types for jsonschema._format

repository.name: typeshed
repository.description: Collection of library stubs for Python, with static types

issue.body:
The annotated type for the `raises` argument on format checkers was

    Exception | tuple[Exception, ...]

when it should read

    type[Exception] | tuple[type[Exception], ...]

---

This is a mistake I introduced in #7950 . So far, there have been two or three issues found with those changes, depending on how you count. I will try to make smaller changes to `jsonschema` stubs in the future to avoid creating this situation again.

body:
This issue seems to exist for any runtime evaluation of `type[X]`, not just in type aliases:
```py
def f() -> type:
    return type[int]  # error: Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable
```
This still happens when using the `--python-version 3.10` option.

issue.title: `type` class cannot be used as a generic
issue.body:
(moved from python/typeshed#6218)

It seems as of python 3.9, `type[...]` has a special case for returning `GenericAlias` while not having a `__class_getitem__`, this causes issues when using it in favour of `typing.Type`:

```sh
$python -c 'type[int]'  # Works
$ mypy -c 'type[int]'
<string>:1: error: Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable
Found 1 error in 1 file (checked 1 source file)
```

I stumbled upon this issue with `python 3.9.7`/`mypy 0.910` but it is still there as of `mypy 0.920+dev.8b9ade2`

issue.title: () Subscripted `type` with new union syntax in `TypeAlias` incorrectly reports 'Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable'

labels.name: topic-type-alias
labels.description: TypeAlias and other type alias issues

issue.body:
```py
from typing import TypeAlias, Union

A: TypeAlias = type[object] | object  # error: Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable
B = type[object] | object  # error: Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable
```

[playground](https://mypy-play.net/?mypy=latest&python=3.10&gist=e3676e4db4dbfd4ad61e548392badd7c)

issue.title: `Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable` error inside `reveal_type(type[type])`

labels.name: false-positive
labels.description: mypy gave an error on correct code

issue.body:
When `type[type]` is used inside `reveal_type()` i get `Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable` error:
```py
reveal_type(type[type]) # Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable
                        # Revealed type is "Any"
```

**Expected Behavior**
I expect behavior similar to this example:
```py
X: type[type[type]]
reveal_type(X) # Revealed type is "Type[Type[builtins.type]]"
```
So i expect this:
```py
reveal_type(type[type]) # Revealed type is "Type[Type[builtins.type]]"
```


**My Environment**
- `mypy 0.961 (compiled: no)`
- no command-line flags, no config file
- `CPython 3.10.4`
- Windows 10

issue.title: Type[type] is not indexable when in Union

labels.name: false-positive
labels.description: mypy gave an error on correct code

labels.name: topic-type-alias
labels.description: TypeAlias and other type alias issues

issue.body:
The following code:
```python3
t = type[str] | type[bytes]
```
produces the following output:
```shell
$ mypy test.py
test.py:1:5: error: Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable  [index]
    t = type[str] | type[bytes]
        ^
Found 1 error in 1 file (checked 1 source file)
```
This looks like a false positive to me.

```shell
$ mypy --version
mypy 0.961 (compiled: yes)

$ python3 --version
Python 3.10.4

$ lsb_release -d
Description:	Ubuntu 22.04 LTS
```

issue.title: Vertical line in place of Union does not pass the types check
issue.body:
Example of a commit with this issue:
https://github.com/fipl-hse/2022-2-level-labs/pull/33/commits/0da5b89f7b9c37ac09f811119bc8471aa88c89dd

main.py line 186:
```
if not (is_dic_correct(frequencies, False, str, int | float) and my_isinstance(top, int) and top > 0):
```

Check types output:
```
lab_1_keywords_tfidf/main.py:186: error: Argument 3 to "is_dic_correct" has incompatible type "Type[str]"; expected "Union[int, float, str, Tuple[Any, ...]]"  [arg-type]
lab_1_keywords_tfidf/main.py:186: error: Unsupported left operand type for | ("Type[int]")  [operator]
```

body:
Hm, on current master, two of them work, but other two (with lowercase `type`) fail with different error
```
tstalt.py:3: error: Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable  [index]
tstalt.py:5: error: Value of type "Type[type]" is not indexable  [index]
```
cc @JukkaL who recently worked on this.

issue.title: Fix issues with type aliases and new style unions
issue.body:
Fix aliases like this and other aliases involving new-style unions:
```
A = type[int] | str
```

Fixes #12392. Fixes #14158.
